awd_titl_txt: CPS: Synergy: A Layered Framework of Sensors, Models, Land-Use Information and Citizens for Understanding Air Quality in Urban Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Poor air quality has been linked to not just adverse health effects such as increased incidence of cardiac arrhythmia, lung cancer, heart disease, and mortality, but also to the vitality of a region?s economy. These issues are particularly important in cities such as Salt Lake City (SLC), where topography, climate, and urban expansion combine to create some of the worst air quality episodes in the country.  Cities like SLC currently rely on small numbers of expensive sensors placed across a large geographic area to measure air quality, making local, neighborhood-level measurements impossible to determine. Meanwhile, new commodity technologies are leading to fine-grained, community-based strategies for measuring and communicating air quality. Leveraging both of these approaches, this project will develop and deploy a dense, distributed, and dynamic air quality cyber-physical framework -- focusing on fine particulate matter and using SLC as an urban testbed -- to produce neighborhood-level estimates of air quality.  The framework includes a network of low-cost sensors, hosted and maintained through a citizen science effort and maker-kit approach.

This research will result in novel developments in three areas:  (i) sensor development that focuses on dramatically reducing cost and a movement toward cheap, wearable, passive sensors; (ii) computational modeling that combines heterogeneous sensor measurements with information about weather, topography, and land use patterns; and (iii) visualization interface design that communicates air quality estimates over space and time, coupled with related uncertainty measurements. Each of these areas requires a multidisciplinary approach that integrates existing and novel insights about sensor networks, computational modeling, and sense-making of data, as well as leveraging an engaged and connected community of residents through citizen science.

por.por_cntn:
The project, CPS: Synergy: A Layered Framework of Sensors, Models, Land-Use Information and Citizens for Understanding Air Quality in Urban Environments (AQ&U) has had substantial impacts on education, understanding air quality at the neighborhood scale, and citizen science. AQ&U developed an accurate, reliable and scalable cyber-physical framework for estimating air quality at a fine-grain in both space and time, and it developed an engaging way to communicate air quality and estimates of measurement uncertainty to the public. It led to the deployment of approximately 150 air quality sensors in the Salt Lake Valley, and the project?s air-quality data is accessible a public-facing website (aqnadu.org). This project addresses a critical challenge for this region, exposure to particulate matter pollution during wintertime inversions and due to wild fires. AQ&U?s work has been commercialized (through a new startup company, Tetrad Sensor Network Solutions, LLC), and through this commercialization its reach has expanded to four additional communities (Chattanooga, TN; Cleveland, OH; Kansas City, MO; and Springfield, MA) in the United States. 

 

This project has also contributed to the training of three undergraduate students, five graduate students, and two postdoctoral fellows.  It has resulted in 12 peer-reviewed publications/conference proceedings, numerous presentations from the community to the international level, a NSF-sponsored ScienceNation video, regional press coverage, and one best paper award in Chemical Engineering Education. Fifteen undergraduate students were active participants in six publications, and two publications boast undergraduate students from underrepresented groups as lead authors. Additionally, two undergraduate students from an underrepresented group received a best undergraduate paper award from AIChE?s environmental division. Furthermore, student team members won the annual AIChE STEM outreach competition in 2019 and 2020 with teaching modules supported, in part, by this project. Through new collaborations with investigators in atmospheric science and sociology, AQ&U also advanced knowledge about wildfire smoke transport in complex terrain and about the relationship between socioeconomic levels, air quality at school locations, and environmental justice in Salt Lake City.

The project has broader impacts on the smart-cities /internet of things (IoT) communities, air-quality policy makers, environmental justice, individuals seeking to minimize air pollution exposure, and social and behavioral science. Specifically, the air quality vizualizations help communities make sense of the imperfect sensor data and to help develop strategies to address poor air quality.
